title: 105_s1280
content: The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act Amendments of 1997 includes provisions such as restriction on waiver authority, organizational capacity assistance, oversight, allocation formula, and technical amendments. SEC 2. RESTRICTION ON WAIVER AUTHORITY. Amends Section 101(b)(2) of the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 to allow the Secretary to grant a waiver for up to 90 days if extreme circumstances prevent an Indian tribe from complying with requirements. SEC. 3. ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY; ASSISTANCE TO FAMILIES THAT ARE NOT LOW-INCOME. The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act is amended to include a description of the entity responsible for carrying out activities, including relevant personnel and organizational capacity. The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 is amended to include assistance for Indian families that are not low-income, providing evidence of housing need that cannot be met without such assistance. The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 is amended to eliminate waiver authority for small tribes, expand authority to review Indian housing plans, and enhance oversight for noncompliance with affordable housing requirements. The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 is amended to address noncompliance with affordable housing requirements, with the Secretary taking action if recipients fail to comply. Additionally, audits and reviews by the Secretary are enhanced for oversight. The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 is amended to designate housing entities by Indian tribes as non-Federal entities subject to audit requirements under Chapter 75 of Title 31, United States Code. The Secretary may arrange and pay for required audits, withholding amounts from assistance to cover audit costs. The Secretary may pay for audit costs under Chapter 75 of Title 31, United States Code for housing entities designated by Indian tribes. Additional audits may be conducted to ensure timely and eligible activities are carried out by recipients. The Secretary may pay for audit costs for housing entities designated by Indian tribes to ensure compliance with eligible activities and certification. Onsite visits by Department of Housing and Human Development officials may be conducted as part of reviews and audits. The Secretary will review reports provided by recipients to verify the accuracy of information. The Secretary allows recipients to review and comment on reports for at least 30 days. After considering recipient comments, the Secretary may revise the report and make it publicly available within 30 days. The reviews and audits of recipients' reports are subject to further examination. The Secretary may adjust grant amounts based on reviews and audits of recipient reports submitted under this Act. SEC. 7. ALLOCATION FORMULA. Section 302(d)(1) of the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 is amended to provide a formula for Indian tribes with fewer than 250 public housing units. The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 is amended to provide modernization assistance to Indian tribes based on the average annual funds provided under the assistance program for the period of fiscal year 1992 to fiscal year 1997. The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 is amended to include a hearing requirement. The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 is amended to include a hearing requirement for certain actions taken by the Secretary. The Secretary may take action if a recipient fails to comply with key provisions of the Act resulting in unauthorized federal fund expenditure, without a hearing, but must provide notice to the recipient. The Secretary may conduct a hearing within 60 days of providing notice to determine whether to continue the action or take another action under this subsection. SEC. 9. PERFORMANCE AGREEMENT TIME LIMIT. Section 401(b) of the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 is amended to specify compliance objectives in a performance agreement with the Secretary. The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 is amended to include compliance objectives in a performance agreement with the Secretary, lasting for 1 year and subject to review upon termination. If the recipient has made a good faith effort to meet the objectives, the Secretary may enter into an additional performance agreement. The Secretary may enter into an additional performance agreement for the specified period if the recipient fails to make a good faith effort to meet compliance objectives, leading to non-compliance with the Act. SEC. 10. BLOCK GRANTS AND GUARANTEES NOT FEDERAL SUBSIDIES FOR LOW-INCOME HOUSING CREDIT. The text chunk discusses an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code regarding buildings receiving home assistance or Native American housing assistance. Amendments of 1997 state that buildings with 40 percent or more of residential units occupied by individuals with income 50 percent or less of the area median gross income are exempt from certain provisions. Amendments in 1997 exempt buildings in designated cities with 40% or more residential units occupied by low-income individuals from certain provisions. The amendment in this section changes the percentage to 25%. This amendment applies to determinations under the Internal Revenue Code after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 11 of the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 makes technical and conforming amendments, including changes to the table of contents and authorization of appropriations. In fiscal years 1998 through 2001, $10,000,000 is authorized for emergencies and disasters, with additional funds available for grants. Certification requirements under the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 are repealed, and terminated housing contracts will have funding implications for subsequent fiscal years. In fiscal years 1998 through 2001, $10,000,000 is authorized for emergencies and disasters, with additional funds available for grants. Certification requirements under the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996 are repealed, and terminated housing contracts will have funding implications for subsequent fiscal years. Dwellings under section 302(b)(1) will be considered as such for each fiscal year.
